questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because his teachers have noticed him staring blankly on multiple occasions over the past month. These episodes last for several seconds and occasionally his eyelids flutter. He was born at term and has no history of serious illness. He has met all his developmental milestones. He appears healthy. Neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. Hyperventilation for 30 seconds precipitates an episode of unresponsiveness and eyelid fluttering that lasts for 7 seconds. He regains consciousness immediately afterward. An electroencephalogram shows 3-Hz spikes and waves. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vigabatrin is contraindicated in epilepsy syndromes that are associated with absence seizures because it can precipitate them. Vigabatrin is instead the first-line treatment for West syndrome, especially if the underlying cause is tuberous sclerosis. West syndrome, however, presents during infancy and is typically associated with epileptic spasms not absence seizures.

B) INCORRECT:

Lamotrigine is only used as a third-line drug for seizure prophylaxis in childhood absence epilepsy because more effective drugs are available. Lamotrigine may be used as a first-line drug for seizure prophylaxis in Lennox-Gastaut syndrome. Although LGS may result in absence seizures in most patients, they are atypical absence seizures that would result in spike-and-wave EEG waves with a frequency < 2.5-Hz (unlike the 3-Hz waves of typical absence seizures). Lamotrigine is also a first-line drug for seizure prophylaxis in older patients with partial-onset seizures.

C) INCORRECT:

Pregabalin is contraindicated for the prophylaxis of absence seizures as it can precipitate them. Pregabalin is instead used as an adjunctive in adults with simple partial seizures.

D) INCORRECT:

Clonazepam is not a first-line drug for seizure prophylaxis in patients with absence seizures. It may be used for adjunctive seizure prophylaxis in patients with refractory absence seizures, but there are no randomized control trials to support this practice.

E) INCORRECT:

Carbamazepine is contraindicated in absence seizures because it increases the risk of developing absence status epilepticus and/or generalized tonic-clonic seizures. Carbamazepine is the most widely used antiepileptic drug and may be used in all ages for epileptic syndromes that are not associated with absence seizures. Carbamazepine is especially effective for focal seizures or secondarily generalized tonic-clonic seizures with a temporal lobe focus (e.g., temporal lobe epilepsy).

F) CORRECT:

Ethosuximide is the drug of choice for seizure prophylaxis in childhood absence epilepsy. The probable mechanism of action for ethosuximide is inhibition of the low-threshold T-type calcium channels in the thalamus that are thought to be responsible for the rhythmic 3-Hz discharge seen in absence seizures. Ethosuximide halves the incidence of absence seizures in at least 90% of patients and decreases the incidence by more than 90% in half of all patients.

G) INCORRECT:

Phenytoin is contraindicated for the prophylaxis of absence seizures as it can precipitate them. Phenytoin is instead used for seizure prophylaxis in patients with focal seizures and/or generalized tonic-clonic seizures, and as a second-line drug to treat status epilepticus.

H) INCORRECT:

Levetiracetam is currently not a first-line drug for seizure prophylaxis in patients with absence seizures. Currently, levetiracetam is only licensed for adjunctive seizure prophylaxis in adolescents and/or adults with myoclonic seizures (especially juvenile myoclonic epilepsy), focal seizures, and/or generalized tonic-clonic seizures.
questions.hint: This patient's frequent short episodes of staring, inattentiveness, and eyelid fluttering while maintaining muscle tone and lacking a postictal phase are characteristic findings of absence seizures. Reproduction of these findings via hyperventilation and EEG findings of a 3-Hz spike and wave pattern further support the diagnosis. The onset of absence seizures before the age of 8 years indicates childhood absence epilepsy.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother to establish care after moving to a new city. He lives at home with his mother and older brother. He was having trouble in school until he was started on ethosuximide by a previous physician; he is now performing well in school. This patient is undergoing treatment for a condition that most likely presented with which of the following symptoms?

choices.text: Regression of verbal skills and stereotyped hand-wringing
Limited attention span and poor impulse control
Overwhelming daytime sleepiness and hypnagogic hallucinations
Episodic jerky movements of the arm and impaired consciousness
Frequent episodes of blank staring and eye fluttering
Recurrent motor tics and involuntary obscene speech

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Regression of skills and stereotyped hand-wringing are characteristic of Rett syndrome, a rare inherited disorder associated with progressive degeneration of locomotor and fine motor skills that presents with progressive loss of cognitive (especially verbal) skills. While this could explain the patient's poor school performance, Rett syndrome almost exclusively affects females and is not treated with ethosuximide.

B) INCORRECT:

Limited attention span and poor impulse control are hallmarks of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). Patients present with inattention and appear hyperactive, restless and impulsive, which may lead to impaired school performance. Although this patient's trouble in school could have been mistakenly attributed to inattention, his disorder is most likely caused by episodes of unresponsiveness instead of hyperactive behavior. Moreover, ADHD is treated with stimulant medication (e.g., amphetamines) and behavior therapy, not ethosuximide.

C) INCORRECT:

Narcolepsy is characterized by excessive daytime sleepiness, cataplexy, hallucinations upon waking or falling asleep (hypnagogic hallucinations), and sleep paralysis. Narcolepsy is treated with stimulant medications such as modafinil, rather than ethosuximide, making this diagnosis unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Episodic jerky movements of the arm and impaired consciousness are symptoms suggestive of a complex partial seizure. While most antiepileptics can be employed in its treatment, ethosuximide is not among them. This makes this diagnosis unlikely, given the patient's medical history.

E) CORRECT:

Absence seizures are generalized seizures with characteristic transient periods of unresponsiveness, which may manifest as episodes of blank staring and eye fluttering. There is usually no preceding aura, or postictal drowsiness or confusion. Ethosuximide blocks thalamic T-type calcium channels and is an effective treatment for absence seizures, as indicated here by this patient's improving performance in school after therapy was started.

F) INCORRECT:

Recurrent motor tics and involuntary obscene speech are characteristic of Tourette syndrome, a severe neurological tic disorder that typically presents in boys and is often associated with ADHD. Although it might explain this patient's poor school performance, neither Tourette syndrome nor ADHD is treated with ethosuximide.
questions.hint: Ethosuximide is the drug of choice for childhood absence seizures.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother 30 minutes after having had a seizure. When her mother woke her up that morning, the girl's entire body stiffened and she started shaking vigorously for several minutes. Her mother also reports that over the past few months, her daughter has had multiple episodes of being unresponsive for less than a minute, during which her eyelids were fluttering. The girl did not recall these episodes afterwards. Upon arrival, she appears drowsy. Neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy to prevent recurrence of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Phenytoin is an antiepileptic drug that inhibits voltage-gated sodium channels in the brain, thereby reducing the excitability of neurons. It is used primarily for tonic-clonic and focal seizure prophylaxis and in status epilepticus as an initial therapy in combination with benzodiazepines. However, it is not very effective against absence seizures, which this patient also has.

B) INCORRECT:

Lorazepam is an intermediate-acting benzodiazepine that is used in acute seizure treatment to abort status epilepticus. However, it is not effective in the management of seizure disorders. In addition, long-term benzodiazepine use can lead to tolerance and dependency, which makes it inappropriate for seizure disorder management.

C) INCORRECT:

Ethosuximide is an antiepileptic medication that reduces excitability in the brain by blocking thalamic T-type calcium channels. It is first-line treatment in childhood absence seizures, which usually presents with multiple episodes of unresponsiveness lasting less than a minute, as seen in this patient. However, childhood absence seizures usually have an earlier onset, at around age 6. Furthermore, this patient had an early morning tonic-clonic seizure, against which ethosuximide would be ineffective.

D) INCORRECT:

Topiramate is an anticonvulsant that blocks sodium channels and increases GABA action, which reduces excitability in the brain. It is used in the treatment of partial (focal) and tonic-clonic seizures. In addition, it can also be used in absence seizures refractory to other medications. Because this patient has not received previous treatment, topiramate would not be indicated.

E) CORRECT:

Valproate is an anticonvulsant that inhibits GABA transaminase and sodium channels. It is first-line treatment in juvenile absence epilepsy. Absence seizures can occur on their own, in which case they can be successfully treated with ethosuximide. However, 75% of patients with juvenile absence epilepsy have concomitant tonic-clonic seizures for which ethosuximide is ineffective.

Other indications for valproate include bipolar disorder and prevention of migraine and cluster headaches.
questions.hint: Multiple episodes of unresponsiveness lasting less than a minute with eyelid fluttering and concomitant early morning tonic-clonic seizures is suggestive of juvenile absence epilepsy. The first-line medication for long-term management is an antiepileptic drug that can also be used as a mood stabilizer in bipolar disorder.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room by his mother for a generalized tonic-clonic seizure that occurred while attending a laser light show. His mother says that he has been otherwise healthy but he often daydreams. Over the past several months, he has reported recurrent episodes of jerky movements of his fingers and arms. These episodes usually occur shortly after waking up in the morning. He has not lost consciousness during these episodes. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Carbamazepine is an antiepileptic drug that inhibits voltage-gated sodium channels in the brain, which reduces the excitability of neurons. Carbamazepine is not used in patients with juvenile myoclonic epilepsy, as it may induce absence status epilepticus.

B) INCORRECT:

Tiagabine is an anticonvulsant that inhibits GABA reuptake. Tiagabine is typically used to treat focal seizures, with or without impairment of consciousness. Tiagabine is not used in patients with juvenile myoclonic epilepsy because of its potential to aggravate generalized seizure types (such as myoclonic or absence status epilepticus).

C) CORRECT:

Valproic acid (valproate) is the first-line therapy for juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (Janz syndrome). Valproate inactivates sodium channels and inhibits GABA metabolism, increasing the concentration of GABA. Major side effects include hepatotoxicity (so liver function studies must be monitored), pancreatitis, and neural tube defects (valproate is contraindicated in pregnant individuals).

D) INCORRECT:

Vigabatrin is an antiepileptic medication that reduces excitability in the brain by inhibiting the catabolism of GABA. It is primarily used to treat infantile spasms and refractory complex partial seizures. It is contraindicated in patients with juvenile myoclonic epilepsy due to its potential to aggravate it or induce absence status epilepticus.

E) INCORRECT:

Phenytoin inhibits voltage-gated sodium channels in the brain, which reduces the excitability of neurons. Phenytoin is used primarily for tonic-clonic and focal seizure prophylaxis and may also be used as a second-line drug in status epilepticus. Phenytoin is not used in patients with juvenile myoclonic epilepsy because it may aggravate absence seizures and myoclonic jerks.

F) INCORRECT:

Ethosuximide is the first-line treatment for absence seizures. This medication reduces excitability in the brain by blocking thalamic T-type calcium channels. Although this patient has a vague history that could indicate absence seizures (he often daydreams), the combination of myoclonic jerks that occur shortly after awakening and generalized tonic-clonic seizures are more suggestive of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy.

G) INCORRECT:

Diazepam is a long-acting benzodiazepine that acts by binding GABA-A receptors and increasing the frequency at which they are open and inhibiting neuronal excitability. Benzodiazepines are used in patients with status epilepticus, but they are not indicated as first-line agents in patients with juvenile myoclonic epilepsy.
questions.hint: The combination of myoclonic jerks that occur shortly after awakening, generalized tonic-clonic seizures, and a vague history that could indicate absence seizures (he often daydreams) in this teenager is suggestive of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy.

questions.text:
The parents of a 6-month-old girl bring her to the emergency department after observing a cluster of whole-body jerks that resembled exaggerated startles and persisted for approximately 10 minutes. The child first began experiencing intermittent and subtle shoulder jerks approximately 4 weeks ago, but the jerking is now more intense and occurs daily in clusters upon awakening. The parents report that she has become less socially interactive and can no longer sit independently.
She appears well but is sleepy. She has eczema and a few areas of hypopigmentation on her back and extremities. She has mild head lag, truncal hypotonia, increased patellar reflexes, and 3 to 4 beats of ankle clonus bilaterally.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Infantile spasms (IS) is a catastrophic type of epilepsy that begins in infancy. The incidence of IS ranges from 2.0 to 3.5 per 10,000 live births. Most affected infants present at 3 to 7 months of age, with 90% presenting by 12 months. The cardinal features of IS are flexor, extensor, or mixed flexor-extensor spasms; a distinct and chaotic electroencephalogram (EEG) pattern called hypsarrhythmia; and developmental regression or arrest. West syndrome is a triad of IS, hypsarrhythmia, and intellectual disability.

IS can be associated with a number of different metabolic and genetic conditions (such as Downs syndrome or tuberous sclerosis complex [TSC]), as well as brain-structure abnormalities due to trauma, infections, or cortical malformations.

Infants with suspected IS should undergo neuroimaging and EEG as part of the initial diagnostic workup. Potentially treatable causes of IS, such as pyridoxine-dependent seizures, should be considered early. The goal of treatment is complete cessation of the spasms and resolution of the hypsarrhythmia. Prompt recognition and early treatment of IS can result in better overall outcomes.

A significant percentage of infants with TSC have IS. Infants undergoing evaluation for IS should have a careful skin examination with a Wood (ultraviolet) lamp for the hypopigmented ash-leaf macules that are characteristic of TSC; neuroimaging confirms the diagnosis and reveals cortical hamartomas called tubers. A diagnosis of TSC has important treatment implications for IS. The preferred initial treatment for IS in the United States is adrenocorticotropin hormone, whereas the preferred first-line treatment for patients with TSC is often vigabatrin.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in an infant with whole-body jerks occurring in clusters and loss of developmental skills is infantile spasms.

B) INCORRECT:

Startle disease (or hyperekplexia) manifests in the neonatal period as an exaggerated startle or generalized stiffening (sometimes accompanied by apnea) in response to visual, auditory, or tactile stimulation. The EEG is normal in patients with startle disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy classically manifests in the teenage years, and patients have normal development.

D) INCORRECT:

Infants with myoclonic epilepsy have a normal developmental trajectory, and the EEG background activity is normal between seizures.

E) INCORRECT:

Dravet syndrome, or severe myoclonic epilepsy in infancy, can manifest as a prolonged, generalized, or focal seizure associated with fever. However, developmental decline and myoclonic seizures do not typically develop until the second year of life in patients with Dravet syndrome.

questions.text:
A 6-month-old boy with trisomy 21 is evaluated for recent onset of abnormal movements. His parents report that one week ago, they began noticing episodic flexing of his trunk that lasted for 1 to 2 seconds. Initially, the episodes happened once or twice daily, typically while the patient was falling asleep, but for the past 2 days, they have been happening at least five times per day while he is awake. The episodes are not associated with feeding.
During the physical examination, you witness three episodes, 30 seconds apart, in which the patients head flexes toward his abdomen, and he screams. The rest of the examination reveals stigmata of trisomy 21 but is otherwise unremarkable.
An electroencephalogram shows a disorganized background with high-amplitude waves and multifocal spikes.
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient most likely has infantile spasms (IS), given the features of his movements and his history of trisomy 21. The seizures associated with IS are brief, symmetrical contractions of the musculature in the neck, trunk, and extremities. They typically last up to 5 seconds, frequently occur in clusters, and are associated with a distinct electroencephalographic (EEG) pattern of hypsarrhythmia, which consists of a disorganized background with high-amplitude waves and multifocal spikes. Children with IS may also experience developmental regression.

IS can be either symptomatic or cryptogenic. Patients with symptomatic IS have a clearly defined underlying cause or significant developmental delay before the onset of spasms. In contrast, patients with cryptogenic IS have no underlying cause identified and no preceding abnormalities in development. Approximately 50% of symptomatic IS cases have a prenatal cause, such as central nervous system malformations, intrauterine insults, neurocutaneous syndromes such as tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC), metabolic disorders, and genetic syndromes such as trisomy 21. The incidence of infantile spasms is higher in the setting of TSC or trisomy 21 than in the general population.

An EEG evaluation should be conducted as soon as IS is suspected. Once the diagnosis is confirmed, the underlying etiology becomes the focus of evaluation because it may affect the choice of treatment. Treatment modalities for IS include adrenocorticotropic hormone and vigabatrin, with variable efficacy; response to treatment depends on the underlying disorder, if identified. In particular, patients with TSC should receive vigabatrin as first-line therapy.

Spasms usually cease by 3 to 5 years of age, but seizures are reported in 60% of patients with IS even after cessation of spasms. Outcomes and prognosis are typically more favorable in cryptogenic IS than symptomatic IS. Patients with symptomatic IS are more likely to develop epilepsy or to have abnormal development than those with cryptogenic IS.

Key learning point: The most appropriate management for suspected infantile spasms is immediate electroencephalography to confirm the diagnosis, followed by rapid initiation of treatment (typically with adrenocorticotropic hormone).

B) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and referral to physical therapy could be appropriate strategies if a patients abnormal movements were behavioral or developmental in nature. However, that is not likely the case here, and these management approaches would only delay diagnosis and opportunity for intervention.

C) INCORRECT:

A histamine-2-receptor antagonist is used to treat gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Although the symptoms of GERD can be confused with seizures or other abnormal movements, the possibility of IS should be investigated before GERD is considered, especially in a patient with trisomy 21.

D) INCORRECT:

Phenobarbital has not proven effective for the treatment of IS but could be considered if another seizure syndrome were to develop.

E) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and referral to physical therapy could be appropriate strategies if a patients abnormal movements were behavioral or developmental in nature. However, that is not likely the case here, and these management approaches would only delay diagnosis and opportunity for intervention.

questions.text:
The parents of a developmentally normal 4-year-old girl report that she has been having episodes of behavioral arrest and staring. During these episodes, she is unresponsive to auditory or tactile stimulation, but then she immediately returns to baseline and resumes her prior activity. The episodes occur multiple times each day and last up to 10 seconds each. Her parents also note that she requires repeated instructions to carry out simple tasks.
If an evaluation confirms the most likely diagnosis in this patient, which one of the following treatments should be AVOIDED because it could worsen her symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids, such as methylprednisolone, have been used to manage many different epilepsy syndromes. Although these medications are not appropriate first-line therapy, they would not be expected to worsen seizures.

B) INCORRECT:

Valproic acid and ethosuximide have comparable efficacy in the management of childhood absence epilepsy, but ethosuximide has fewer adverse effects, making it the better initial choice.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's symptoms are consistent with absence seizures. Childhood absence epilepsy typically begins between the ages of 4 and 8 years and is characterized by short, frequent staring spells with no postictal sequelae. These absence seizures often interrupt conversation or activity multiple times per day and cannot be interrupted by calling the childs name or with tactile stimulation.

Absence episodes are typically provoked by hyperventilation, and this can be tested in the office. The electroencephalogram is pathognomonic and shows generalized 3-Hz spike- and slow-wave bursts with otherwise normal background activity. Problems with attention are characteristic of childhood absence epilepsy, independent of seizure frequency.

Carbamazepine and oxcarbazepine can worsen both absence seizures and myoclonic seizures, so their use should be avoided in these settings. Carbamazepine is primarily used to treat partial-onset seizures, which are typically characterized by episodes of facial numbness, twitching, hypersalivation, and dysphagia that usually occur at night or on awakening.

Key learning point: The antiepileptic medication that can worsen absence seizures is carbamazepine.

D) INCORRECT:

Valproic acid and ethosuximide have comparable efficacy in the management of childhood absence epilepsy, but ethosuximide has fewer adverse effects, making it the better initial choice.

E) INCORRECT:

Methylphenidate is used to treat attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder, which can include behavioral inattentiveness that is interruptible; this patients symptoms are not consistent with that diagnosis. Although methylphenidate would not treat this patients absence seizures, it should not make them worse.
